thread.title: Trump Trip To Ohio To Sign Pro-Coal Legislation Reportedly Canceled
thread.title_full: Trump Trip To Ohio To Sign Pro-Coal Legislation Reportedly Canceled

author: Jack Davis
title: Trump Trip To Ohio To Sign Pro-Coal Legislation Reportedly Canceled
text:
Trump Trip To Ohio To Sign Pro-Coal Legislation Reportedly Canceled "Make no mistake about it ..." by Jack Davis February 13, 2017 at 2:21pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
A bill signing by President Donald Trump that reportedly had been scheduled for Ohio later this week has been canceled , according to multiple reports. 
The Youngstown Vindicator had reported over the weekend that Trump was coming to the Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport in Vienna on Thursday. It cited “sources with information about the visit.” 
The news outlet reported that the purpose of Trump’s visit was to sign a bill throwing out a rule approved by the Barack Obama administration in its waning days. Advertisement - story continues below Online Attacks Launched Against Singer For Wearing Trump Dress 
The “Stream Protection Rule,” which was designed to limit what could be dumped into steams, was denounced by Republicans as over-regulation. Earlier this month, Congress voted to end the rule through what is known as the Congressional Review Act. "The stream protection rule is really just a thinly veiled attempt to wipe out coal mining jobs.” @SpeakerRyan https://t.co/kQuKcAFxEa 
— House Republicans (@HouseGOP) February 2, 2017 
“Make no mistake about it, this Obama administration rule is not designed to protect streams,” said Rep. Bill Johnson, R-Ohio, who helped to reverse the rule. “Instead, it was an effort to regulate the coal mining industry right out of business.” Advertisement - story continues below 
Trump’s signature on the bill has been expected ever since it received congressional passage. As a candidate, Trump said he would support easing regulations that negatively impact the coal sector. 
Wiping out the rule was hailed by employers as a major victory. 
“This is one very, very important step to get coal back on its feet and stop the hemorrhaging of jobs that we’ve seen,” said Luke Popovich, a spokesman for the National Mining Association. 
Stephanie Weiler, a spokeswoman at Peabody Energy, said the company supported “any actions aimed at reining in unnecessary regulations that don’t improve the environment yet harm the economic and jobs landscape.” Advertisement - story continues below
